titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Radio TV Services Records, circa 1937 - 2012 UA.27.02.0001
titlestmt.author: Processed by: Dean Jeffrey; machine-readable finding aid created by: Dean Jeffrey

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-01-09 20:38:52 UTC.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Established in 1954 as part of the Office of Information Services (now the Office of News and Communications,) Radio TV Services supervises the production of materials for radio and television, assists in the preparation of audio-visual materials needed by the university, and promotes the University's exposure to local, state, and national audiences. It makes documentary films, covers events and functions on campus, sets up news conferences in cooperation with local and national media, interviews university personnel, and provides features on students for their home-town media. Collection includes correspondence, subject files, sound recordings (audiocassettes and reel-to-reel tapes), film (16mm), and video tape (U-Matic and 2-inch quadruplex). Notable people documented on film and tape include Keith Brodie, Terry Sanford, Douglas M. Knight, Orin Pilkey, Robert Menzies, Jerry Falwell, Billy Graham, Queen Noor al Hussein, Jesse Jackson, Waylon Jennings, Juanita Kreps, Robert McNamara, Ronald Reagan, William Westmoreland, Desmond Tutu, Elie Wiesel, Reynolds Price, Martin Luther King, Jr., Hubert Humphrey, Richard Nixon, Stokely Carmichael, Kenneth Clark, Sidney Cohen, Adam Clayton Powell, Betty Friedan, B. F. Skinner, Sam Ervin, Alex Haley, Tom Wolfe, Buckminster Fuller, and Cesar Chavez. Subjects include Duke University basketball, football, commencement, convocation, homecoming, the Epoch Campaign announcement, student unrest in the 60s, the Silent Vigil held after the death of Dr. King, the Duke Marine Laboratory, the discovery of the U.S.S. Monitor, oceanographic research, the 1954 Orange Bowl, Joe College Weekend, various campus scenes, Duke Gardens, and the Richard Nixon Library controversy. Completed films include Response to Our Challenge and This is Duke. English.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.
In off-site storage; 48 hours advance notice is required for use.

Use of audiotapes, films, and videotapes from this collection requires the creation of reference copies. Reference copies for a few of the films have been made on VHS and DVD, and if a reference copy exists, it is noted in this finding aid. To arrange for the creation of reference copies of other items, please contact University Archives staff. Although these recordings and films are now stored in a stable environment, their condition and playback quality is unknown.

Electronic records in this collection have been migrated to a library server and digital use copies can only be accessed onsite in the Rubenstein Library Reading Room. To request access, please contact Research Services before coming to use these records.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Copyright for Official University records is held by Duke University; all other copyright is retained by the authors of items in these papers, or their descendants, as stipulated by United States copyright law.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Radio TV Services Records, University Archives, Duke University.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Radio TV Services Records was received by the University Archives as a transfer in 1988; 2008, accession numbers UA88-57, UA2008-0048, UA2008-0065; 2012, accession UA2012-0041.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Dean Jeffrey, November 2005; Patrick Dollar and Tracy M. Jackson, 2015; Hyeeyoung Kim, November 2017.
Accessions described in this collection guide: UA88-57, UA91-53, UA2008-0048, UA2008-0065, UA2009-0047, UA2010-0023, UA2012-0041.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Established in 1954 as part of the Office of Information Services (now the Office of News and Communications,) Radio TV Services supervises the production of materials for radio and television, assists in the preparation of audio-visual materials needed by the university, and promotes the University's exposure to local, state, and national audiences. Harry Durham was the director from 1964-1966, followed by Charlie Braswell, who held the position until 1988.

The office produced a daily news program, The News of Duke, and a weekly radio program, Challenges in Education (which eventually aired on more than 100 stations, including Voice of America and the Armed Forces Network). It also made documentary films, such as Medicine at the Crossroads (1966). It covers events and functions on campus, including trustee meetings, convocations, and protests. It sets up news conferences in cooperation with local and national media, interviews university personnel, and provides features on students for their home-town media.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Collection includes correspondence, subject files, images, sound recordings (audiocassettes, reel-to-reel tapes, and digital audio), film (16mm), video tape (U-Matic, 2-inch quadruplex, and digital video), and multimedia of events related to Duke occurring both on and off campus. There is a detailed subject file on index cards for most of the film and some of the sound recordings, as well as other indexes and notes.

Notable people documented on film and tape include Keith Brodie, Terry Sanford, Douglas M. Knight, Orin Pilkey, Robert Menzies, Jerry Falwell, Billy Graham, Queen Noor al Hussein, Jesse Jackson, Waylon Jennings, Juanita Kreps, Robert McNamara, Ronald Reagan, William Westmoreland, Desmond Tutu, Elie Wiesel, Reynolds Price, Martin Luther King, Jr., Hubert Humphrey, Richard Nixon, Stokely Carmichael, Kenneth Clark, Sidney Cohen, Adam Clayton Powell, Betty Friedan, B. F. Skinner, Sam Ervin, Alex Haley, Tom Wolfe, Buckminster Fuller, and Cesar Chavez. There are also film and recordings documenting Duke University basketball, football, commencement, convocation, homecoming, the Epoch Campaign announcement, student unrest in the 60s, the Silent Vigil held after the death of Dr. King, the Duke Marine Laboratory, the discovery of the U.S.S. Monitor, oceanographic research, the 1954 Orange Bowl, Joe College Weekend, various campus scenes, Duke Gardens, and the Richard Nixon Library controversy. Completed films include Response to Our Challenge and This is Duke.

controlaccess.persname: Brodie, H. Keith H. (Harlow Keith Hammond), 1939-

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence files of Harry Durham and Charlie Braswell, directors of Radio TV Services. The A and B folders are missing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, reports, minutes, memoranda, and other materials concerning the campus radio and TV stations, the introduction of FM broadcasting, public relations, film projects, and other activities.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Extensive subject, and numerical index created by the department. Materials indexed are reel to reel audiotapes (numbered B-1 through B-773), 16mm films (numbered C-1 through C-164 and D-1 through D-8), and scripts (which are not part of the existing collection.) Audio cassettes, some of the 16mm films, and videotapes are not included in the index.

did.unittitle: C-Series Films: Notes for Subject Index, undated

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Original elements for Duke 140 are in Box 17 and Box 20. Audiotape is in Box 12.

did.unittitle: D2 and D3: List of Shots, undated

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Typed list of shots for Film D-2 and a handwritten list of shots for Films D-2 and D-3 of Terry Sanford's inauguration. Film D-2 is in Box 15. Film D-3 is missing from the collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Full title of the script is For Humankind and History: A Time for Greatness at Duke. Film related to the Epoch Campaign is in Box 15 and Box 20. Audiotape of the Epoch Campaign Announcement is in Box 11.

did.unittitle: Letter Re: Quest Without End, Mar. 1, 1961

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Quest Without End was a color sound film about Duke University. A copy of the film and its original elements are in Box 18.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mimeographed shot lists for two of the films in Box 18: Duke vs. N.C. State and Duke vs. South Carolina.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Folder containing press releases, correspondence, black and white photographs, and other printed materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A typed description of the film This is Duke plus a xerox copy of an article about the film from the Alumni Register, Sept. 1954.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A handwritten list of shots from film #C-160, Presentation Ceremony of some type at Duke Homestead.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Original recordings are closed to use. Digitized access copies are available for some recordings. Please contact University Archives staff for more information.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In addition to individuals related to Duke such as Keith Brodie, Terry Sanford, and Douglas M. Knight, a number of other notable people are represented in the sound recordings: Jerry Falwell, Billy Graham, Queen Noor al Hussein, Jesse Jackson, Waylon Jennings, Juanita Kreps, Robert McNamara, Ronald Reagan, William Westmoreland, Desmond Tutu, Elie Wiesel, Reynolds Price, Martin Luther King, Jr., Hubert Humphrey, Richard Nixon, Stokely Carmichael, Kenneth Clark, Sidney Cohen, Adam Clayton Powell, Betty Friedan, B. F. Skinner, Sam Ervin, Alex Haley, Tom Wolfe, Buckminster Fuller, and Cesar Chavez. There are also tapes pertinent to Duke University basketball, commencement, student unrest in the 60s, the Silent Vigil held after the death of Dr. King, the discovery of the U.S.S. Monitor, and oceanographic research.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in the original alphabetical order in which they were received.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: All audiotapes in this series are 1/4 inch tape on open reels. Reels are 7 inch except where noted. This series is indexed by title and by subject in the card file index in Box 3.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Reel-to-reel audiotapes were originally numbered B-1 through B-773. That arrangement has been retained here. Approximately twenty un-numbered tapes are listed at the end of the series in the same order in which they were received.

did.unittitle: Film, C and D series 1951-1974, undated

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: All film in this series is 16mm. The film is stored on a variety of different sized reels and in different sized cans. Sometimes the film is in a can without a reel, sometimes without a core.

Individuals related to Duke include Terry Sanford, Douglas M. Knight, Wright Tisdale, George Allen, Orin Pilkey, and Robert Menzies. In addition to numerous campus scenes, there is footage of the Duke Marine Lab, the ship Eastward, convocation, football from the 1950s, the discovery of the U.S.S. Monitor, the Epoch Campaign announcement, and outtakes from the film This is Duke.
This series is indexed by title and by subject in the card file index in Box 3.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The films in this series were originally numbered C-1 through C-164 and D-1 through D-8. That arrangement has been retained here. A number of unnumbered reels were received by the archives in the same boxes as these films and seem to belong in this series. Films without numbers are listed at the end of the series, arranged in alphabetical order by title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: All film in this series is 16mm. The film is stored on a variety of different sized reels and in different sized cans.
Some of the subjects depicted include football, basketball, the 1954 Orange Bowl, Joe College, campus scenes, Duke Gardens, the Duke Marine Laboratory, commencement, and homecoming.

The film in this series is not indexed in the card file index in Box 3. However, a typewritten list titled Description of Films describes the contents of some of these films, and descriptions from the list have been included in this finding aid. The original list is in Folder 7, Box 16.

Since the majority of these films are numbered using a system other than the one used by Radio-TV Services, and since most of them appear to have been shot before the creation of the department, it is assumed that they were inherited from some other organization.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The films in this series were originally numbered 1 through 46. That arrangement has been retained here. A number of unnumbered reels were received by the archives in the same boxes as these films and seem to belong in this series. Films without numbers are listed at the end of the series, arranged in alphabetical order by title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: All of the film in this sub-series is 16mm on 10 or 12-inch reels. These reels seem to have been packed together simply because they were all about the same size.

Some of the subjects depicted include Duke bands and the Marine Laboratory. There are original elements for the film Duke 140, as well as finished versions of the films Response to Our Challenge, Quest Without End, and This is Duke.

Since these are not numbered using the Radio-TV Department's numbering system, and since most of them appear to have been shot before the creation of the department, it is assumed that they were inherited from some other organization.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Films are arranged alphabetically by title.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Produced for Alumni Affairs, this promotional film is presented as a tour of the campus by a student. It contains footage of campus life, religious activities, commencement, homecoming, Joe College Weekend, classrooms, laboratories, the hospital, professional schools, and Duke Forest. A section towards the end has footage of many senior administrators.

From a note in the University Archives collection file: The film This is Duke University was a 27-minute film done in the 1950s. Fred Whitener photographed most of the film and produced it. Harry Owen did the sound recording and titles. A mechanical engineering student (an announcer for WDBS, who had a good deep voice) did the narration. The film had a musical background. Allan Bone selected the music from records and it was dubbed with narration. Engineering did the sound recording on the equipment in the photograph. The film was shown all over the world, including on cruise ships. The total costs of this first film with sound, including a trip to N.Y. by Fred Whitenener and Harry Owen, was less than $1,000. Dr. Owen said it should be copied to video tape. Harry Owen, 6/12/85.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: Alumni Register, Sept. 1954, pp. 16-17. A copy of the article is in Box 19, Folder 11.

did.unittitle: Film, Unnumbered 3 inch reels, circa 1948-1965, undated

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: All of the film in this sub-series is 16mm on 3-inch reels. These reels seem to have been packed in this box simply because they were all the same size. Most of them appear to have been shot before the creation of the Radio TV Services, so it is assumed that they were inherited from some other organization.

Some of the subjects depicted include homecoming, Joe College, the Marine Laboratory, Duke Gardens, football, other athletics, commencement, various campus scenes, and the Epoch Campaign Announcement.

When they were acquired by the Archives, many of these reels were undated. Most of them, however, are in their original film manufacturer's boxes. Sometimes the box has a postmark on it, indicating when the film was mailed after being processed. In this case, the postmark is used to date the film if there is no other indication of date. Most boxes also have an expiration date-a Develop Before or Process Before date. When there is no shoot date or postmark, the expiration date is used to date the film, under the assumption that it provides a general time period in which the film was shot.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Films are arranged chronologically by shoot date, postmark, or expiration date, followed by films for which no date could be determined. These are arranged in alphabetical order by title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Accession contains video tape (mostly VHS, 2 DVDs, some BetaMax) of events related to Duke occurring both on and off campus. Some topics include NC People (Nan Keohane, Keith Brodie, Richard Brodhead, Terry Sanford); history of Duke stone; Duke Primate Center; Graduate 1997; NCAA championship bonfire; convocations, baccalaureate services, graduations, tributes (John Burness, Jerry Black). Noted speakers include Pres. Brodhead, Pres. Keohane, John Hope Frankin, Cokie Roberts, Janet Reno, George Bush, etc.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Electronic records in this series have been migrated to a library server and digital use copies can only be accessed onsite in the Rubenstein Library Reading Room. To request access, please contact Research Services before coming to use these records.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Electronic records in this file have been migrated to a library server and digital use copies can only be accessed onsite in the Rubenstein Library Reading Room. To request access, please contact Research Services before coming to use these records.
